700621f-b.title: Bronx: Bronx Park - De Lancey's Pine.
700621f-b.text:
(1)
Bronx Park: A view of De Lancey's Pine on the east shore of the Bronx River,slightly north of East 180th Street. Legend has it that American sharpshooters used to hide in its branches and pick off
British soldiers during the Revolution.
1892.
Gift of Randall Comfort.
(2)
Another view of the same, at a later date.
1936.
W. P. A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.
700621f-b.folder: Bronx Park & De Lancey's Pine., Bronx, NY

700622f-a.title: Bronx: Bronx Park - Delancey Pine.
700622f-a.text:
2 - DE LANCEY PINE, Bronx Park, Bronx Borough. Rises 150 feet from the ground, and is near the site of the old De Lancey Mansion of Revolutionary Fame, the rendezvous of the British officers. In the branches of this great tree the Americah sharpshooters used to climb, and from this well concealed place of vantage would pick off the Red Coats stationed at the De Lancey Block House just across the Bronx River.
"Memorial of the fallen great,
The rich and honored line;
Stands high in solitary state,
De Lancey's Ancient Pine."
This tree measures 11 feet, 5 inches in circumference, 3 feet from base.
700622f-a.folder: Bronx Park & Delancey Pine., Bronx, NY

700619f-a.text:

view.

700629f-a.title: Bronx: Bronx Park - P.S. 57 Annex (Bronxdale).
700629f-a.text:
Bronx Park: A view of Public School No. 57 Annex, situated about one hundred yards west of Boston Road and about 150 yards south of Pelham Parkway. It stood formerly on the north side of the old White Plains Road within the village of Bronxdale. The village was later (after 1900) incorporated into Bronx Park. The school was demolished sometime
after 1930.
July 28, 1928
P.L. Sperr
700629f-a.folder: Bronx Park & P.S. 57 Annex (dale)., Bronx, NY

700620f-a.title: Bronx: Bronx Park - Rocking Stone.
700620f-a.text:
9 -ROCKING STONE, Bronx Park. Another "Glacial Waif," left stranded by the masses of ice during the Glacial Epoch. Not wishing to have this grat bowlder in the way of his farm yard, an early owner tried to have it dragged away, but twelve yoke of sturdy Westchester County oxen failed to move it an inch. Yet it is so nicely balanced on a rocky drift that the pressure of a strong finger will easily set it swaying
back and forth.
700620f-a.folder: Bronx Park & Rocking Stone., Bronx, NY
